skill.name: fixing-accessibility
skill.description: Fix accessibility issues in UI components by following WCAG guidelines and best practices.
skill.summary: Guidelines and rules for fixing accessibility issues in UI code.
skill.author: ibelick

security_audit.summary: All static findings are false positives. The skill is a benign accessibility guidelines document containing slash commands for invoking the skill and technical terms related to accessibility (aria-invalid, aria-describedby). No actual security risks detected.

dangerous_patterns.title: False Positive: External Commands Detection
dangerous_patterns.description: Static scanner detected 'Ruby/shell backtick execution' at lines 12 and 15. This is a false positive - the pattern `/fixing-accessibility` is a slash command syntax used to invoke the skill, not shell execution.

dangerous_patterns.title: False Positive: Weak Cryptographic Algorithm
dangerous_patterns.description: Static scanner detected 'weak cryptographic algorithm' at lines 3 and 82. This is a false positive - the scanner misinterpreted technical terms: 'description' (frontmatter field) and 'aria-describedby' (accessibility attribute) as crypto-related terms.

dangerous_patterns.title: False Positive: System Reconnaissance
dangerous_patterns.description: Static scanner detected 'system reconnaissance' at lines 84 and 107. This is a false positive - 'aria-invalid' (accessibility attribute) and media playback guidance were misinterpreted as reconnaissance activity.

content.value_statement: Accessibility issues can exclude users with disabilities from using your product. This skill provides clear rules and practical fixes for common accessibility problems in UI components.
actual_capabilities: Apply accessibility constraints to any UI work in a conversation
Review files against accessibility rules and report violations
Explain why each violation matters with a short explanation
Provide concrete, code-level fix suggestions for each issue
limitations: Does not automatically fix issues - provides guidance only
Does not test or validate accessibility with actual tools
Does not handle complex widget patterns like combobox or treeview
Does not replace accessibility testing with assistive technologies

use_cases.title: Apply Accessibility Rules to New UI
use_cases.description: When building new buttons, forms, or dialogs, invoke the skill to ensure all work follows accessibility best practices from the start.
use_cases.target_user: Frontend developers building new UI components

use_cases.title: Review Existing Code for Issues
use_cases.description: Run the skill against existing UI code to identify accessibility violations, understand their impact, and get targeted fix suggestions.
use_cases.target_user: Developers auditing legacy code for accessibility

use_cases.title: Learn Accessibility Best Practices
use_cases.description: Use the skill as a reference guide to learn about keyboard access, focus management, ARIA usage, and semantic HTML.

prompt_templates.prompt:
/fixing-accessibility

Apply these constraints to any UI work in this conversation.
prompt_templates.scenario: Start a conversation about building UI and want all responses to follow accessibility rules

Review the file against all rules below and report violations (quote the exact line or snippet), explain why it matters (one short sentence), and provide a concrete fix (code-level suggestion).
prompt_templates.scenario: Have a specific file you want reviewed for accessibility issues

prompt_templates.title: Fix a Button
prompt_templates.prompt: How do I make an icon-only button accessible?
prompt_templates.scenario: Ask a specific accessibility question related to the skill guidelines

prompt_templates.title: Fix a Form Error
prompt_templates.prompt: How should I associate error messages with form fields for accessibility?
prompt_templates.scenario: Learn how to handle form validation errors accessibly

output: Violation: Icon button lacks accessible name (line 5)
Why it matters: Screen reader users cannot identify the button action
Fix: Add aria-label or use aria-labelledby to provide accessible name

output_examples.input: How do I make a modal dialog accessible?
output: 1. Trap focus inside the dialog while open
2. Restore focus to the trigger element on close
3. Set initial focus on the first interactive element
5. Ensure proper aria-modal and role='dialog' attributes

best_practices: Prefer minimal, targeted fixes over large refactoring to reduce risk
Use native HTML elements before adding ARIA attributes
Test keyboard navigation manually after applying fixes
Quote exact code snippets when reporting violations
anti_patterns: Do not use div or span as buttons without full keyboard support
Do not add aria attributes when native semantics already solve the problem
Do not remove focus outlines without providing a visible replacement
Do not rely on color alone to convey state or meaning

faq.question: What is the priority order for fixing accessibility issues?
faq.answer: Priority order is: accessible names (critical), keyboard access (critical), focus and dialogs (critical), semantics (high), forms and errors (high), announcements (medium-high), contrast and states (medium), media and motion (low-medium), and tool boundaries (critical).

faq.question: Does this skill automatically fix accessibility issues?
faq.answer: No. The skill reports violations with explanations and fix suggestions, but you must apply the fixes manually to your code.

faq.question: What are accessible names and why do they matter?
faq.answer: Accessible names are what screen readers announce for interactive elements. Every button, link, and input must have a meaningful accessible name so users with visual impairments can understand and navigate the interface.

faq.question: When should I use ARIA versus native HTML?
faq.answer: Always prefer native HTML elements with built-in accessibility. Use ARIA only when native elements cannot express the required semantics. Remember: if you can use a native button, do not use a div with role='button'.

faq.question: How do I test if my accessibility fixes work?
faq.answer: Use keyboard-only navigation (Tab, Shift+Tab, Enter, Escape), screen reader testing (NVDA, VoiceOver), and browser accessibility inspectors. The skill provides guidance but does not replace manual testing.

faq.question: What is focus trapping in dialogs?
faq.answer: Focus trapping keeps keyboard focus inside a modal dialog while it is open. Users should not be able to tab to elements behind the dialog. When the dialog closes, focus must return to the element that opened it.
